Desmearing¶

Desmear the 1-D SAS data (q, I, dI) by method of Lake & Jemian.

$Id: desmear.py 1684 2011-08-25 05:19:03Z jemian $

To desmear, apply the method of Jemian/Lake to 1-D SAS data (q, I, dI).

Source Code Documentation¶

lake.desmear.Desmear(q, I, dI, info, callback, quiet=False)[source]¶

desmear the 1-D SAS data (q, I, dI) by method of Jemian/Lake

Parameters:
  • q ([float]) – magnitude of scattering vector
  • I ([float]) – SAS data I(q) +/- dI(q)
  • dI ([float]) – estimated uncertainties of I(q)
  • info (dict) – dictionary of desmearing parameters
  • callback (object) – function to call after each iteration
  • quiet (bool) – if True, then no printed output from this routine
Returns:

tuple of corrected/desmeared SAS (C, dC)
Return type:

([float], [float])
lake.desmear.FixErr(x, y, dy, z)[source]¶

Estimate the error on Z based on data point scatter and previous error values and smooth that estimate.

Parameters:
  • x ([float]) – independent axis
  • y ([float]) – dependent axis
  • dy ([float]) – estimated uncertainties of y
  • z ([float]) – adjusted dependent axis
Returns:

dz, estimated uncertainties of z
Return type:

[float]
lake.desmear.examine_scatter(x, y, dy, z)[source]¶

Error based on scatter of desmeared data points. Determine this by fitting a line to the points i-1, i, i+1 and take the difference. Add this to dz.

Parameters:
  • x ([float]) – independent axis
  • y ([float]) – dependent axis
  • dy ([float]) – estimated uncertainties of y
  • z ([float]) – adjusted dependent axis
Returns:

estimated uncertainties of z
Return type:

[float]
lake.desmear.moving_average_filter(x, y)[source]¶

Smooth y(x) by a 3-point moving average filter. Do not smooth the end points.

Weight the data points by distance^2 (as a penalty) using the function weight(u,v)=

By its definition, weight(x0,x0) == 1.0.

I speed computation using this definition.

Parameters:
  • x ([float]) – independent axis
  • y ([float]) – dependent axis
Returns:

smoothed version of y(x)
Return type:

[float]
